We see an error with psample.ko module, which can be ignored as linux kernel has default psample module which gets loaded.
```
 opennsl-modules[712]: insmod: ERROR: could not load module /lib/modules/5.10.0-8-2-amd64/extra/psample.ko: No such file or directory

But psample module exists 

admin@str-a7280cr3-2:~$ lsmod | grep knet
linux_knet_cb          20480  0
psample                20480  1 linux_knet_cb
linux_bcm_knet         98304  1 linux_knet_cb
linux_kernel_bde       73728  2 linux_bcm_knet,linux_user_bde
admin@str-a7280cr3-2:~$

```


Building psample with opennsl was removed earlier for Bullseye upgrade https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/8191. Will take it up later if we really need this module to be build here.

This change is verified on all other HWSKUs as well or just Z9332 ?

> This change is verified on all other HWSKUs as well or just Z9332 ?

We only have Z9332F in house for test validation. Other HW SKU will need community that has those devices to try out.  We do this type of changes based on BRCM recommendation which we have done previously as well such as TD3 support where we only have one HW SKU but applied the same across other TD3 based HW SKUs.  The change should only change the behavior during boot time to not unnecessarily generate FDB events for TH3 based ASIC.

the Marvell_armhf build failure has nothing to do with this "BRCM" specific change.  Tried to rerun the failed job once already and same failure as following:

@arlakshm @shi-su Could you help review?

My understanding of currently SONiC behaviors:
1. supporting missing "DEVICE_METADATA" - "bgp_asn"
   - The case appears in https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/wiki/L2-Switch-mode
   - /etc/frr/bgpd.conf will have a `router bgp` line, which is not valid
2. supporting "DEVICE_METADATA" - "bgp_asn" with a value "None"
   - The case appears if /etc/sonic/minigraph.xml miss <DeviceMiniGraph> <CpgDec> <Routers>
   - /etc/frr/bgpd.conf will have a `router bgp None` line, which is not valid
3. supporting "DEVICE_METADATA" - "bgp_asn" with a int value
   - The normal L3 switch config

So right now, we need to fix sonic-device_metadata.yang to support above behaviors. In future, ideally we need to improve the first 2 cases, let /etc/frr/bgpd.conf handles them gracefully.

@prgeor , thank you for reviewing the changes.

As you can see, in this SFP plugin we expose SFP eeprom content through the file cache which is updated each time `get_eeprom_path()` is executed. Some APIs we still implement explicitly through SDK platform calls. Mostly to improve performance. Also, since eeprom is emulated through the file cache, we override `write_eeprom()` to disable write access which does not make sense in this case. Instead, whenever is needed, we implement write APIs explicitly. E.g., `tx_disable()`, `tx_disable_channel()`. The implementation can be extended and/or improved in the future.

Some APIs we still implement explicitly through SDK platform calls. Mostly to improve performance. Also, since eeprom is emulated through the file cache, we override `write_eeprom()` to disable write access which does not make sense in this case. Instead, whenever is needed, we implement write APIs explicitly. E.g., `tx_disable()`, `tx_disable_channel()`. The implementation can be extended and/or improved in the future.

In future when your platform needs to support QSFP-DD then your platform will have to duplicate the code in sonic_xcvr. Currently Xcvrd only collects DOM related info from transceiver, but in future QSFP-DD module will need initialization which has data path link synchronization requirement see ref. [https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/pull/916](https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/pull/916). Xcvrd is platform independent and won't support any platform specific requirement and hence its important for platform to re-use sonic_xcvr which is compliant with various MSA specifications.

@dgsudharsan Do we need any 'default' configuration before the logrotate config was rendered? Have you confirmed that the next logrotate will pick up the new config after rendering? Can you also add a sonic-mgmt test for this?

> @dgsudharsan Do we need any 'default' configuration before the logrotate config was rendered? Have you confirmed that the next logrotate will pick up the new config after rendering? Can you also add a sonic-mgmt test for this?

Yes I tested this scenario  logrotate picks up after rendered. Its only few seconds difference between cron and rendering. 
There are multiple scenarios
1) Onie install - there will be no rsyslog config in logrotate and so it will not be considered for logrotate. However the next time logrotate runs after 10 minutes, there will be rsyslog logrotate config which will be used. 
2) Upgrade - I believe the conf files under /etc would be copied during upgrade and old conf file would be used before rendering and after will pick up the new one
3) reboot - The conf file will already be rendered before reboot and hence that will be used. 

Regarding sonic-mgmt, I don't think there are any test cases although the suite covers logrotate as a utility for all existing tests. 
Do you recommend to write a test case for covering logrotate functionality? If yes I believe that needs to be considered as a separate effort.

AI: DPB config links @praveen-li

> AI: DPB config links @praveen-li

https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/679a4ba602cc4c1ea77b52e1c782e8663d99e03b/tests/config_dpb_test.py#L715 [Build time Config for front end DPB test]

In order to test the functionality of DPB....

1. Setup MCLAG across some ports (i.e. Ethernet0 and Ethernet4 for example sake)
2. Make sure configuration is applied and MCLAG is functioning as expected
3. Run `show interface breakout` to get a full list of supported breakout modes per port
4. Look for the `Ethernet0` key in the results and look for `breakout_modes` under that
5. Pick one of the breakout modes and copy the key
6. Run `config interface breakout Ethernet0 2x50G[25G,10G] -y -f` where the interface is the one you are breaking out and the mode is copied straight from step 5
7. The command should complete without error
8. Run `show interface status` and verify the port has been successfully broken out
9. Run `config save -y`
10. Verify there are no references to the original port in the config (particularly MCLAG config sections)

If this process works without a problem then you can be confident that DPB should work. One thing also to consider, as is mentioned in the yang group meetings is that you should include all possible config options for MCLAG to ensure that Yang is not hung up on anything it may not recognize. 

Please let me know if there are any questions.
